Baby Diego was killed in a bar fight in Buenos Aires after refusing to sign an autograph... A man enters the coffee shop, making his way through the people: THEO FARON (55). Detached, unkempt, scruffy beard glasses, Theo is a veteran of hopelessness. He gave up before the world did.
He was born in 2005, the son of Marcello and Sandra Ricardo, a working class couple from Buenos Aires.... Theo wedges his way to the counter. He orders:

Coffee. Black. Next to him, a 50-year-old woman stares up at the TV, cradling a small dog, tears rolling down her face. Theo waits, glancing at the old plasma TV without much interes ON TV: The face of “Baby” DIEGO (18), the most famous boy the world, a fair-haired teenager who has never lacked anything, smiling a practiced smile.

Baby Diego struggled his entire life with the celebrity status thrust upon him by being the world’s youngest person. ON TV: Stock footage of Diego's life. His baby portrait.. video footage of Diego learning to walk... Diego (8), at first communion... Diego (14), ambushed by paparazzi... (CONTINUED)

Different accounts suggest that Diego spat in the face of a Zed who asked for an autograph, which began the fight that ended in his death. The Zed was lynched by the angry crowd shortly thereafter. Theo's coffee arrives. He lays exact change on the counte and starts to make his way out. Passing through the crowd Other people crying. Two grizzled POLICEMEN sip coffee, watching the news.
Diego, the youngest person on earth, was 18 years, 4 months, 2 days, 16 hours and 8 minutes old. Theo leaves the cafe.

Theo walks out with his coffee, facing the day. People walking along quietly, bundled up. Some with dogs. It’s cold. It’s wet. It’s sad. It’s London. SUPER: LONDON, 2024 A.D. A short distance from the cafe, Theo sets his coffee cup a post box. Slow traffic rolls past. Mostly “old” cars, ‘ models, some older. A couple of ‘18's. Motorized rickshaw scoot around the edges. A double decker bus passes with metal mesh on the windows. Bicycles. A billboard, showing a stern-faced leader flanked by the idealized profiles soldiers and policemen: “KEEPING ENGLA ALIVE”. Surveillance cameras on lamp posts and building sides with tiny disclaimers: “For Your Protection.” Theo takes out a flask from his pocket, unscrews the top, about to pour it into his coffee, when behind him -- KA-BOOM! A BOMB EXPLODES inside the cafe, blowing out the windows, rocking the ground. Theo reels with the blast, knocked off balance... Smoke pours through the shattered facade of the cafe. Wai of PAIN, as people stagger out, covered in residue, holdi their wounds, bleeding. A woman missing an arm. Theo regains his balance, shell-shocked, holding his ears FADE TO BLACK. (CONTINUED)
TITLE: “THE CHILDREN OF MEN”

Through a train window covered by steel mesh, a billboard passing by: “GIVE HUMANITY A HAND - GET A FERTILITY TEST” Theo rubs his ringing ears, watching the desolate green landscape. POCK! POCK! Projectiles smack against side of the train, the steel mesh protecting the windows. Theo looks: A gang is hurling rocks and bottles. 20-year-old males, s with painted faces -- these are ZEDS. The youngest generation on earth, nothing to lose, it all ends with th After throwing their load, the Zeds recede, disappearing behind a billboard: “IS YOUR NEIGHBOR A TERRORIST? REPORT ALL SUSPICIOUS ACTIVITY.”

Fucking Zeds. Hurl a few rocks, crawl back into their cracks. Theo looks back to the train. Two middle-aged COPS face h on the opposite seat, commuting home after a long day. cOP 1 It’s our fault. We indulged the whiney pricks for too long. The last generation. End of the line. Big deal. (gestures to Cop 2) Rick’s boy, he’s what, 20? He got dealt the same hand. He didn’t quit. Good boy, that Scottie. Joined the force, what, a year ago?
Uh huh. Cop 2 fumbles with something in his hand: a strip of pill

Two weeks ago, he and some other rookies walked into a Zed ambush. A real zedding. Outnumbered, two to one, three to one -- hell, seven to one! When we got there later, the floor was covered with blood. Blood and teeth. Zed’s teeth. And the rookies...not a bloody scratch. (MORE)
cop 1 (CONT'D) They pummelled the pissant Zeds. You could almost feel sorry for them. Those zeds have numbers, but no discipline, no technique. And more important, no pride.

Yeh. Cop 2 pops one of the pills into his mouth. cop 1 Pride. That’s what set us apart. That’s why England’s still alive. Look at the rest of the world. It’s hell out there. Theo looks out the window. Graffiti on a wall: “LAST PERS TO DIE PLEASE TURN OFF THE LIGHTS”.
Theo steps off the train. Policemen patrol the platform, some with German Shepherds. He looks around, spotting an older man across the way. He walks toward him.
Hey, amigo. JASPER PALMER was young in the 60’s, and has refused to l go of his youth ever since. Thick glasses, wispy beard, l hair, he is probably the coolest 75-year-old on the plane
Hi, Jasper. The two old friends greet each other warmly.
How's it going?
Quite groovy. Quite, quite groovy.

Abandoned fields with ruined farms, exhausted barns that like scarecrows. A car crosses, its headlights cutting through the darkeni blue, passing machinery rusting on the fallow land. A Vol sedan, circa 2009, not mint but still reliable.
Many get killed?
‘ THEO (OFF) I don’t know. Fuck, the place was packed.
Who set the bomb?
Fuck knows. My ears are stiJ.l ringing.
You mean the “eeeeeee”? INT. JASPER’S CAR - DRIVING -- CONTINUOUS Jasper watching his mirrors, navigating the sparse road. Theo in the front seat, massaging his ears. A beat.
(continues) «+. "eeceecece”?
Ub huh.
You know, pigs are planting most of them. Then they blame Foogies, the 5 Fishes, or whoever they want.
Right after it went off, there were some wounded, crawling out. A bloody woman, holding the hind of a dog. And the people on the street, walking by.
What did you do?
I left.
I’m glad they missed you, amigo. Losing you and Baby Diego on the same day would be too much grief to bear. (off Theo’s look) You did hear about Baby Diego.
You kidding me? (CONTINUED )
They say he was completely wasted.
Baby Diego was always wasted.
He was a wanker.
Yeah, but he was the youngest wanker on the planet.
Quite true. Quite, quite true. Theo smiles. The headlights illuminate a wooded area.
The Volvo slows down, and makes a left turn, going off th road, stopping in front the woods. Jasper and Theo get out. Jasper walks to the middle of th empty road, looking both ways.
(starting a joke) So there‘s this supper. Scientists and wise men, you know, Human Project, that sort of bullocks.
(rolling with it) Yeah... Assured the coast is clear, Jasper walks toward a row of bushes in front of the trees, illuminated by the headligh
They‘re throwing around theories about the ultimate question: how is it that human beings haven‘t had babies in 18 years? Theo walking with Jasper toward the bushes.
The biologist blames genetic experiments that altered DNA. The environmentalist says that pollution and bio-experiments poisoned the water. You know, the typical jada jada. (CONTINUED)
Jasper removes one of the bushes -- it’s not rooted.
A New Age bloke claims Mama Nature is merely protecting herself. Theo removes another bush. This is a false hedge, hiding tiny dirt path behind it.
Then they all look at this English scientist, who hasn‘t said a word, he just keeps eating. Jasper stops Theo.

They ask him, “So, what do you think? Why don’t people have babies anymore?” The English bloke looks at them, he’s chewing on a wing... (thick English accent) “I haven't a clue,” he says. “But this stork is quite lovely, isn’t it?” Jasper playfully hits Theo.
Waaah! You get it -- he’s eating a stork!
(smiles) Stork. That’s funny.
Through the woods, Jasper’s car crossing the dirt path, t headlights on.
How's Janice?
She’s lovely.
Jasper navigates the dirt path carefully.
(sighs) Tends to wander off occasionally. (MORE )
I found her last week on the other side of the brook. Mud all over her nightgown, . shivering a death of cold, poor thing.
I’m sorry.
When she’s her normal self, she’s been mentioning it. Quietus.
Quietus?

She feels worthless. She feels a burden to me. When she’s lucid, she remembers what we used to be. Through the windshield, in a clearing in the trees, visib in the last light of day: a low-tech, jury-rigged eco-hou complete with primitive solar panels and a grass roof.
The Stones’ "Ruby Tuesday” plays. JANICE (70) sits ina chair, staring ahead. She was young in the 60’s, and now old. The light is gone from her eyes, her face a blank ma
Hi, Sweetie. Jasper kisses her. Janice does not react.
Theo’s here. He came for a little visit. Theo, remember? Your Rebel With a Lost Cause? Jasper motions Theo over.
Hi, Janice. No response from Janice. She is staring at a wall of phot Her lifetime frozen in images. A shrine to her past.
She's not always like this. She’s in and out. INT. JASPER’S KITCHEN -- NIGHT Jasper and Theo at the kitchen table, eating vegetable so (CONTINUED)

A couple weeks ago, I came on this Dutch bloke, lost out back in the woods. Poor soul, wasn’t much left of him. Remember the pictures of those starving wretches in Ethiopia? Same thing, only blond. He said he‘’d escaped from Bexhill. They dug a tunnel under the fence and came over, 200 of them. Mostly French, Spaniards... (emphasis for Theo) ...a few Americans. They were crossing no man’s land. Soldiers caught them. Lined them up, shot them down. 200 hundred refugees. Unarmed. Bam. Just like that. Keeping England Alive. It didn’t make the news.
Not surprising.

Somehow this bloke escaped, got through no man’s land, got over that hill. I gave him some food. Amigo, he told me some spooky stories about what’s happening in Europe. Atrocities you'd never believe. And the look in his eyes. Jasper eats a spoonful of soup, looking at Theo.
It’s sick. What humans can do to each other. Theo ponders a potato.
I offered to hide him. He refused. Said he had to get to London. Said he had friends there. He left. All the way to London, no papers.
He won‘’t make it.
I know. They both eat a spoonful of soup.
But I’d like to think he would.  10. INT. JASPER’S GREENHOUSE -- NIGHT A make-shift affair, grow lights coaxing marijuana plants into bloom. Theo and Jasper chill, Jasper rolling a joint

Business has been slow. Daddy government gives pills and anti-depressants as part of your ration... (shows joint) +.-and the Buddha is still illegal! Most of my weed now goes to Bexhill. A bloke buys it from me and smuggles it over. Guess what he does. His real job.
Border cop.
Bravo. He smuggles it through no-man’s land. Jasper fires a joint.
(offers Theo a hit) Want some? Theo shakes his head.

Jasper, you’re taking the whole thing too personally. In 80 years, humanity will disappear. So what? Ninety-eight percent of the species that roamed around earth have gone extinct. Jasper takes another hit. Theo nods.
The dinosaurs had a pretty good run of it. Now it’s our turn. What would we be so damn special? Just because we left behind a few interesting piles of rocks?
And some books. Some really awesome books. And those really smashing symphonies. (CONTINUED)

Dylan. The two men smile and fall quiet.

We made a bullocks of the whole thing, didn’t we? Maybe God is ready for a little peace and quiet. INT. JASPER’S HOUSE -- NIGHT Janice still staring at the wall. Theo comes to her. He takes the hair brush she is holding. And begins brushing long gray hair. Among the photos on the wall, one taken at a demonstratio catches Theo’s attention: a younger Janice and Jasper, locking arms with Theo, defiant and long-haired, and a yo woman with the same attitude. Theo carries a 2-year-old b in a baby backpack. A placard for “Global Democracy” can read behind them.

Through a window, we see identical functional apartment buildings on a foggy morning. Next to the window: an old plasma wide-screen TV displays the time. A digit changes -- 8:30. The TV turns on. ON TV: A woman reads the morning news. War torn streets. Militia’s marching. Citizens watching fearfully out their windows. A 50-year-old soldier in fatigues and beret, a Dixie flag flying behind, gives a speech to a crowd in fr of the ruined facade of Camden Yards.

...the American city of Baltimore fell to the Southern Alliance after months of furious street battles. It is seen as the biggest setback to the national government since the invasion of Northern California by the Oregon Alliance. The national government in D.C. has steadily lost popular support since its bombing of Cincinnati seven years ago in an attempt to eradicate militia strongholds. Reflected in the window: CLICK! a light on a side table g on. A form gets up slowly, sitting up on a bed... it’s Th shaking out the cobwebs, his head foggier than London.  12. EXT. STREET’ -- DAY Seven people, men and women, standing with their hands up against a brick wall. Police dogs growl and sniff at thei heels. Policemen linger behind them.
All the past historical events, the so- called facts, flow to one point... Theo walks past. He’s dressed for the day in a worn tweed jacket, a leather pack strapped over his shoulder.
(continues) .+-which we call the present.
Theo enters a gate fringed with barbed wire.
(continues ) And then there are all the events which have yet to occur... Not the grand hails of Oxford, rather, a cluster of one- storey concrete buildings, circa 2000.
{continues ) +--the future.
A security machine swallows his leather case as Theo stan with his arms spread, a Guard frisking him.
(continues ) The moment where the past and the future meet is the tip of both cones.
Theo, somewhat animated, draws two “V” cones on a black board, the tips touching each other.
(continues ) This tip is not only a moment. It’s a perception, and there are as many perceptions as people on this planet. (CONTINUED)

Theo faces the sizeable lecture room, three quarters empt Students stare back at him blankly. People in sleeping ba in back. A man snores in the front row, his pants wet, th urine dripping to the floor.
Any questions?

SIRENS, screaming from police cars, racing by, disappeari into the distance. Theo walks on the sidewalk. A billboard, soothing graphic blue on blue: “QUIETUS -~- you can find relief.” The sidewalk strewn with trash, lethargic breeze. A young couple, embracing, kissing in the open. Theo walks by, leather case over his shoulder. He’s holdi a book, reading as he walks: “Salem’s Lot” by Stephen Kin The young couple breaks their embrace. They begin to foll Theo from behind. He does not notice, reading about a boy who got himself locked inside a vampire’s room. The couple follows, pulling ski masks over their heads. As Theo approaches the corner, a van appears on the stree skidding to a stop, blocking his path. He slows down... A motorcycle comes from behind, skidding to a stop, block his street side. Theo pauses, confused -- The ski masked couple upon him, he pulling out a burlap s she pulling out a pistol. And the van door slides open, showing a masked man holdin semi-automatic gun. Theo reacts, backing away -- The woman sticks the gun into his ribs, whispering an ord

Quiet. The burlap sack comes over Theo's head. She shoves him through the van door. The motorcycle revs, ready to go. The man hops on behind. The woman jumps into the van, the door slides shut. (CONTINUED)
The motorcycle peels off in one direction. The van tears off the other way. INT. KIDNAPPER’S ROOM -- DAY Blackness.

Not so tight...bring some water... put your hood on... The burlap sack comes off. Newspapers glued on the walls, covering them over. Theo is cuffed to a chair. A light shines in his face. A Tall Man in a mask holding it.

You are under the jurisdiction of the 5 Fishes. Your basic human rights will be respected. You will be expected to keep this encounter confidential. To ensure this, you will be under constant surveillance, as you have been for the last two months. The 5 Fishes have eyes everywhere. Do you need water? Theo nods, cotton-mouth.
Water.
Are the handcuffs necessary?
Unfortunately, yes.
(an order) Uncuff him.
I‘don't think --

Do it. The Tall Man gestures. A Short Man (PATRIC) goes behind T and begins unfastening the cuffs. Another hooded man give him a glass of water. A woman in a mask approaches, walking with a limp. (CONTINUED)
“The only reason to breathe is to make a difference.” Theo reacts, taken aback. The woman sits down, facing him
Those are your words, remember? “The only reason to breathe is to make a difference.”

You want to know the truth? I got that from a Chinese fortune cookie. The woman takes the mask off. JULIAN TAYLOR is Theo’s age and although life has taken a harder toll on her, she sti radiates the beauty of someone who believes. A scar runs along the side of her face. Theo is stunned. He recovers with a smirk.
Not bad for somebody whose been dead for six years. She smiles.

(to the others) I met Theo when we were 20, during an anti-globalization demonstration in Seattle. He was a man of ideals, dreadlocks and hemp. We locked eyes while chanting “WIO OUT”. Julian locks eyes with Theo.

(chanting) “WTO OUT! WTO OUT!” And by time the police attacked, we were making out. We kissed as the tears ran down our faces from the tear gas. We fell in love. We were going to change the world -- our love was going to change the world. You know, the John and Yoko bug. Though Julian addresses the half dozen people in the room her eyes on Theo. They are the only two without hoods. He checks his coat. (CONTINUED)
‘ THEO Can I have my flask?

Theo was pissed that all the money for health and education was going to army contractors. So he had this idea. We would chain ourselves to the sculpture in front of the Boeing corporate headquarters. Naked.
Naked was your idea.

We got shy, stopped at our underwear, thank god, and we chained ourselves to the sculpture. And we threw away the key. Full commitment. Now we're waiting for the employees to show up. Waiting for the TV cameras to show up. And it’s cold. And nobody is showing up. It gets colder. So we start yelling. “Hello? Help?” I mean, where’s a surveillance camera when you need one? It’s getting even colder. Finally, a patrol car comes. The cops get out, they're looking at us. We‘re chained, we’re shivering, we're in our underwear. Julian and Theo looking at each other, reliving this mome
(laughing) Cops says, “What are you doing?” And you say, “Protesting.” Cop says, “Come back tomorrow.” And I said, “Why?” Cop says--
“It’s Columbus Day.”
Yeah. They smile, looking at each other. A moment.
Is this why I’m here? To reminisce about the good old days?
I need your help. (CONTINUED)
Can I have my flask?
They’re in some sort of basement room with no windows. Th sips his flask. Julian smokes a cigarette.
Death suits you.
(smiles) You get used to it. They made a big deal about it in the papers, didn’t they? That unfortunate gas explosion.
(recalling) Uh huh.
My stove was electric. -
There was a body.
When the bomb exploded, it blew me down the stairs. But there was Algerian refugee staying at my flat. Fatima. That’s the charcoal they found. Poor thing.
(pissed) You could have called. You could have told me.
What was the point?
It’s courtesy.
I’m sorry. The only way for me to stay alive was to stay dead. Theo looks at Julian with tenderness.
And the limp... was that the...explosion? (CONTINUED )
The scar was the explosion. The limp is from prison. {points to her left ear) And the hearing loss. And the nightmares.
Ahuh...
Eight years. Isle of Skye. Julian stubs out her cigarette.
You always got off on martyrdom.
I need an exit visa, Theo. (off his look) Not for me. There’s a girl we need to get out of the country. If they find her, they will kill her.
What’d she do?
I'm not allowed to go into detail. But you have to trust me. You have to do this.
There’s nothing I can do.
Teddy Phillips offered you a position with the Noah Project three years ago. He’s the Minister of Culture.
It’s a bullshit project, a million people starving to death in Madrid, and we march in and save the Goyas --
That’s not the point. He can get you a visa. He’s your friend. You never asked your friends for help. Julian looks at Theo. (CONTINUED )
This girl is in trouble, Theo, and we can help her.
I kicked idealism.
She’s 21. Twenty-one. This lands with Theo. Julian knows it -- she expected it.
Dylan would have been her age.
That‘s low.
That’s how strongly I feel. I never asked you for anything before, did I? Off Theo, knowing that she hasn't.
Theo in back facing the rear, blindfolded. PATRIC (25) dr ~- Irish, dreadlocks, committed. Facing Theo is LUKE (45) moral authority, practiced compassion, unwavering certain
You understand that disclosing Julian’s identity would put her in extreme jeopardy. Quite frankly, everyone opposed her taking this risk.
She’s stubborn.
She‘s a true believer.
You’re Luke Grissom, right? (no response) The priest. I met you before. At that London thing. Silence. The two men remembering London.

The London massacre unleashed so many demons. Not only the military coup. The famine, the Zed event... Theo remains quiet. LUKE ; I’m sorry about what happened to you. I can’t imagine that kind of loss. Luke pulls on his ski mask. The van slows down. Patric pulls on his mask.
(to Theo) You may take off your blindfold. Theo pulls off his blindfold, blinking with the sudden li Luke hands him a piece of paper and a coin.
Call this number if you need to contact us. The token is for the bus. The van stops. The door slides opens.

Theo steps out of the van at a bus stop. A billboard show young couple tenderly holding a creature which looks impossibly similar to a baby. A doll. A slogan: “LOVE IS WHAT YOU GIVE.” In smaller print: “Now with body temperat and breathing motion.”

This mission is a good deed. I don’t need to tell you that Julian is only involved with good deeds. The door slides shut as the van drives off, leaving Theo the midst of a dozen lingering prostitutes, oblivious to security cameras rigged on the bus stop, a few tiny pooch tapping around. A double-decker with steel meshed windows coming down the street.

A Rolis Royce passing through a heavily guarded restricte gate, leading into the pristine London Mall.  21. INT. ROLLS ROYCE - DRIVING -- Day A uniformed chauffeur drives, Theo in back, now dressed i worn-out suit, looking out the window: On the London Mall, well-dressed citizens on their aftern outing, some walking their dogs, which are dressed in matching outfits. Some dressed in chaps, riding horses. T privileged minority. A restricted zone.

The chauffeur stops at a security gate at the entrance to Southwark bridge. He hands papers to a Security Officer. Guards check under the car with mirrors. Dogs sniff for bombs. They are waved through.
Coming over the bridge: an imposing brick structure, its square tower dominating the gloomy sky: the modern Tate Museum.

The Rolls Royce parks, a security guard opening the door. Theo gets out. Dogs sniff at him, surveillance cameras training over. A government official comes to meet him, extending his hand, smiling. Theo mumbles something. The official explodes with a forced laugh.
Theo crosses through a body scanner. A screen outlines hi skeleton and solid objects, zipper, coins, his flask.
The Official leads Theo through a hall hung with painting arriving at a door, leaving him there, walking away. Theo enters...

Theo is awed. In the middle of the marble hall, under the soft glow of a skylight dome, standing alone, in its perfection, inviting, Michelangelo's David. ‘The real thi Theo is drawn to the sculpture -- WOOF! Two Irish Mastiffs laying on the floor in front of David. Theo doesn’t speak dog, but knows that means stop. Deep growls, the Mastiffs sit up. (CONTINUED )

From behind the David, a man appears, THEODORE “Teddy” PHILLIPS. Around Theo’s age, but looking younger, Teddy i dressed in T-shirt and jeans. The fragile enthusiasm of someone who found an external reason to hold on.
We couldn’t save “La Pieta’”. It was already smashed by the time we got there. But this is rummy, eh?
My Mom had a plastic one in the bathroom. It was a lamp. Teddy approaches Theo.
Hey, bro. Teddy and Theo embrace.

An endless corridor, hung with masterpieces on both walls Teddy throws a tennis ball down the corridor, the Mastiff chase after it, shrinking in the distance. Teddy and Theo carry drinks. Rembrandt's self-portraits a as they pass.
+-.the self-portraits. Scattered around the world. Pain in the ass putting them together. We have most of them. We lost the one at the Frick. That thing in New York was a real blow to art.
Not to mention people.
This one blows my mind. His last one. He stops in front of Rembrandt’s final self-portrait.
Look at him. An old Dutch bloke. Filled with remorse. He’s saying something. Can you tell what he’s saying? Theo looks at the portrait. (CONTINUED)
“Oh, well...”

Exactly. This bloke did some of the wickedest masterpieces in human history, and here he is. At the end of his days. Looking at you. Regretful, mischievous... “Oh, well.” An old Rembrandt looks down at them.
Planes drop bombs on civilians. Black and white cubist mayhem. Theo and Teddy stand in front of Picasso’s “Guernica”. The real thing. The Mastiffs sit nearby.
I sent you some tasty French wine for your birthday, I hope you got it --
Yeah, I meant to call. Thank you.
How are you doing, bro?
Not so well. I think I need to change course. Try something different.
I must say, I was astounded you were still interested.
You gotta admit, it’s kind of kinky.
Wasting precious social resources to assemble an art collection that will be enjoyed by no one.
Trading guns for art.
Noticias, bro. Latin America se acabé. Italy finito. France c’est fini. Germany kaput. Sayonara Japan. Bye, bye America. We used to try to save the world, but it was too late. (MORE) (CONTINUED)
The world chose to save itself instead. We might as well save what made us great.
Ahun.
You still don’t get it. Do you good to get you out of your cave, bro. Teddy looks at Theo -- silently acknowledging his friend’ rough time.

We got the Hermitage, and saved most of the Reik. (beat) Paris is not going to hold. Quel dommage. They’re letting us have a peek at the Louvre before the looters get to it. You'll have to be quite selective.
My Aunt had a Mona Lisa in her living room. Teddy smiles, gives Theo a friendly pat.
It’s so rummy you're doing this, bro.
Theo and Teddy hang, drinking a bottle of 2004 Chateau Margeaux, looking down on London. The Thames flows by, St Paul’s shows off, the day prepares to end. Quiet.
I'll need a pair of exit visas.
A pair?
There’s this girl.
Paris n’est plus la ville des amants. It's real hell down there.
I know, but you know. (CONTINUED )
(smiles) You dog. Something serious?
A couple of bruises. Teddy opens a small silver case. He takes out a pill, offering it to Theo, who shakes his head, staring at him.
What?
You amaze me. What keeps you going? In a hundred years, there won’t be one sad fuck left to remember you. What is it?
You really know what it is, bro? I just don’t think about it. Teddy pops the pill, washing it down with wine.
ON THE SCREEN: “A Hard Day's Night”. The four lads escapi from a hoard of fans...

(singing) “Can’t buy me love...” Theo pushes through a thick red curtain, entering the mos empty theatre. He walks down the aisle. He takes a seat. ON THE SCREEN: An empty treeless park, the lads frolickin gleefully, falling all over each other. Goofy abandon. A VOICE behind Theo:
Don’t turn around. Do you have it? Theo takes an envelope from his pocket, reaching it back
Please put it under the seat. Theo puts the envelope under the seat. The man behind him takes it. It’s Luke. (CONTINUED )
Thanks.
It’s a joint visa.
What does that mean?
She’s my companion. She can only leave the country with me.
Why did you -~ ?
It's what they gave me.
So you’ll have to come.
I‘'m not going. Tell Julian I did what I could. Theo stands to leave.
What are we supposed to do?
Have a democratic assembly, or one of those things you guys like.
Faron -~
I've seen the movie. I know how it ends. ON THE SCREEN: The lads‘ fun comes to an abrupt end when are confronted by a stern COP.
(in the movie) Do you realize this is private property?

(in the movie) Sorry, sorry...  27. INT. QUIETUS AUDITORIUM -- DaY Rolling clouds across a glorious blue sky, touched with colors of a gently fading sun, a glimpse of heaven. You almost don’t notice the pixels. Profiles of faces lying down on soft pads, staring at the clouds projected on the ceiling. Mostly older men and wom some middle-agers, and a few in their youth. Soothing mus suffuses the ambience, and a gentle female voice:

Forgiveness. Experience forgiveness. Dwell in forgiveness. Forgiveness towards those who purposely caused you pain. Forgiveness. Forgiveness towards those who unwittingly caused you pain. Forgiveness. Forgiveness towards yourself. Forgiveness. Forgiveness. Dwell in forgiveness. The participants rest on the floor, as if entering a gent sleep. They are dying. It’s peaceful.
